results.title: Mongolian Princess costume
results.credit_line:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
results.brief_description:
From seller: A Mongolian Princess costume worn in the 1987 multi Oscar-winning drama The Last Emperor. This stunning costume was worn when the 15 year-old Pu-Yi (Wu Tao) wed’s the ‘old’ government chosen first wife and Empress, 17-year old Wan Jung.
The multi-layered costume consists of a thick white quilted gown with ties to the front, a red rayon brocade under robe overprinted in gold with panels in mulberry green and gold appliqué, high padded shoulders, tall collars, and cuffs trimmed in grey Astrakhan and Mongolian lambswool, and finally a waistcoat in maroon velvet and green brocade, overprinted in gold trimmed with antique fabric appliqués on the front and back panels. There are no sizes marked on this wonderful costume and it remains in excellent condition.
This comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-05. Sound and Colour → MI-05-C03

results.title: Miniature Magic
results.brief_description: Some of the biggest set pieces in film and TV are actually the smallest. Big scenes can be too complicated or expensive to film with huge, life-size sets, so production teams create detailed miniatures and use camera tricks to make them appear as the real thing.

constellations_primary.name: Sci-fi miniatures
constellations_primary.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

results.description:
Some of the biggest set pieces in film and TV are actually the smallest. Sometimes big scenes are too complicated or expensive to film with huge, life-size sets so production teams create detailed miniatures of locations and settings, and then use camera techniques to trick the audience into thinking they’re seeing the real thing.

This model represents that approach and references schlocky 1950s sci-fi films, like It Came From Outer Space (1953) and The War of the Worlds (1953), which often used miniatures for their out-of-this-world plots. Miniatures have since been used in blockbusters like Star Wars (1977), Alien (1979) and Batman (1989). Often, they’re created just to be destroyed – like the White House in Roland Emmerich’s Independence Day (1996).
description_for_label:
Some of the biggest set pieces in film and TV are actually the smallest. Sometimes big scenes are too complicated or expensive to film with huge, life-size sets so production teams create detailed miniatures of locations and settings, and then use camera techniques to trick the audience into thinking they’re seeing the real thing.

This model represents that approach and references schlocky 1950s sci-fi films, like It Came From Outer Space (1953) and The War of the Worlds (1953), which often used miniatures for their out-of-this-world plots. Miniatures have since been used in blockbusters like Star Wars (1977), Alien (1979) and Batman (1989). Often, they’re created just to be destroyed – like the White House in Roland Emmerich’s Independence Day (1996).

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Worlds → MW-02. Set Design → MW-02-C05

results.title: Mikhail Kaufman in Dziga Vertov’s Chelovek s kinoapparatom (Man with a Movie Camera)
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.
results.title_for_label: Mikhail Kaufman in Dziga Vertov’s Chelovek s kinoapparatom (Man with a Movie Camera)
results.description: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
description_for_label: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
